abstract.text: Load descriptive metadata for media assets and their tracks.

legalNotices.copyright: Copyright © 2025 Apple Inc. All rights reserved.

inlineContent.text: Media container formats provide metadata that describe their content. You can retrieve it to access information about the media such as the title, artwork, and creation date. AVFoundation models metadata values using the

class. A metadata item represents a single value like a movie’s description or poster image. This class provides a simple, consistent interface to work with metadata, regardless of the underlying container and metadata formats.
provides several ways to access its metadata. You can retrieve all of its metadata by loading the value of its
property. Alternatively, you can retrieve a subset of items that are common to all of the metadata formats it holds by loading the value of its
property.
To retrieve format-specific collections of metadata, like
or
, call an asset’s
method, passing it a specific
to load. The example below iterates over the
an asset contains, and loads each format’s metadata items to process their values.

code: // A local or remote asset to inspect.
for format in try await asset.load(.availableMetadataFormats) {
let metadata = try await asset.loadMetadata(for: format)

inlineContent.text: After you load a collection of metadata, you can filter it to specific values using the class methods of
. The example below shows how to use the
method to find items with an identifier of

code: // Find the title in the common key space.
guard let item = titleItems.first else { return }

inlineContent.text: A metadata item’s filtering methods return collections of items instead of a single instance. In many cases, the returned collection contains a single element, but if the media contains localized metadata, or if you’re retrieving data from the common key space and the same value exists in multiple key spaces, the item returns a distinct value for each.
Retrieve the data a metadata item holds by loading its
property, which is an object that adopts the
and
protocols. You can manually cast the value to an appropriate type, but it’s safer and more convenient to use the metadata item’s type conversion properties. Instead of loading the
property, load its
, or
properties as appropriate to convert it to a specific type. For example, the code listing below shows how to retrieve the artwork associated with an iTunes music track as a data value:

code: // Filter metadata to find the asset's artwork.
// Retrieve a Data object that contains the image data.
guard let imageData = try await artworkItem.load(.dataValue) else { return }

abstract.text: Work with audiovisual assets, control device cameras, process audio, and configure system audio interactions.
An object that models timed audiovisual media.
Loads an array of metadata items that the asset contains for the specified format.
A structure that defines keys for extra metadata attributes.
A structure that defines metadata formats.
The iTunes metadata format.
The QuickTime metadata format.
A structure that defines identifiers for metadata formats.
An identifier that represents the title of the media.
A metadata item for an audiovisual asset or one of its tracks.
Returns metadata items for the specified identifier.
An object that filters selected information from a metadata item.
A structure that defines a metadata key.
A structure that defines a metadata key space.
A mutable metadata item for an audiovisual asset or for one of its tracks.
The formats of metadata that an asset contains.
The metadata items that an asset contains for common metadata identifiers.
The value of the metadata item as a data value.
The value of the metadata item as a date.
The metadata items that an asset contains for all metadata identifiers.
The value of the metadata item as a number.
The value of the metadata item as a string.
The value of the metadata item.
Load media assets from files and streams to inspect their attributes, tracks, and embedded metadata.
A protocol that objects adopt to provide functional copies of themselves.
The group of methods that are fundamental to all Objective-C objects.
